items.title: An HTML element reunion
items.content:
ğŸš€ Frontend Focus

#â€‹605 â€” August 9, 2023 | Read on the web

A Blog Post with Every HTML Element?Â Almost. â€” Taking 18 months to come together, this post makes a brave attempt to squeeze every HTML element (including some former elements like <marquee> and <blink>) into a single place. Itâ€™s a fantastically retro-feeling reunion that starts off feeling a little dull but rapidly picks up theÂ pace, even if poor <applet> doesn't makeÂ theÂ cut..

Patrick Weaver

Practical CSS Layouts with Jen Kramer â€” Join Jen for this extensive video course and learn to code complex layouts using CSS Grid and Flexbox. The course covers responsive design, handling images, styling, navigation and more via a series ofÂ exercises.

Frontend Masters sponsor

WordPress 6.3 â€œLionelâ€ Released â€” Hailed as a â€œmomentous releaseâ€, the universally popular CMS includes a new Site Editor experience, the ability to create and sync block â€˜patternsâ€™, new design tools, keyboard shortcut changes, style revision tracking, along with performance and accessibilityÂ improvements.

MatÃ­as Ventura (WordPress)

An Update on Chrome Security Updates: Shipping Security Fixes to You Faster â€” In an effort to reduce the â€œpatch gapâ€ and get security fixes out faster, Chrome is now shipping weekly Stable channelÂ updates. This doesn't affect the cadence of milestone updates, though, so Chrome 200 is still some wayÂ off.Â ğŸ¤­

Amy Ressler (Google)

âš¡ï¸ IN BRIEF

  • You may start to see OpenAI's 'GPTBot' in your logs, as the company recently launched its own web crawler â€” which in turn sparked blocking efforts by website owners and creators.

  • FranÃ§ois Beaufort shares what's new in WebGPU in Chrome, including WebCodecs integration, video playback improvements, and more.

  • What's the biggest, valid z-index value you can specify in CSS? It may be â–¶ï¸ larger than you think.

  • The way in which downloads appear in Chrome has changed.

  • A request has been made for the Chromium project to reconsider JPEG-XL support (which it had sought to not support). Lots of related chatter on Hacker News about this one.

ğŸ“™ Tutorials, Articles & Opinion

Introducing Project IDX: An Experiment to Improve Full-Stack, Multiplatform App Development â€” A new project from Google â€”Â itâ€™s a full browser-based IDE (built atop the same tech as VS Code) that includes support for most full-stack JavaScript frameworks, cross-platform previews, and deploying to Firebase. You can sign up for theÂ waitlist.

Google

An Introduction to htmx, the HTML-Oriented Dynamic UI Library â€” A look at what htmx is, how it aims to simplify dynamic web development, and how you can harness its potential to enhance your web developmentÂ process.

James Hibbard

Join the React Native EU Conference with a 10% Discount Ticket ğŸ”¥ â€” Sign up for the biggest React Native conf in Europe. Check the agenda to see whatâ€™s awaiting you on Sept 7-8 inÂ WrocÅ‚aw!

Callstack sponsor

âœ¨ Â Coding the Stars: An Interactive Constellation with React ThreeÂ Fiber â€” The Supabase team built a Web-based visualization in the form of an animated sky filled with stars, where each star represented a user signup. If youâ€™ve never experimented with React Three Fiber or creating visual effects before, this is a good introduction walking through the key parts of theirÂ approach.

Francesco Sansalvadore (Supabase)

What Does It Mean for Web Browsers to Have a 'Baseline' â€” Back in May we shared news on Baseline, a new project that aims to clarify what developers can rely on across browsers and the web platform in general. Mary recaps why it matters, how it will hopefully work, and even touches upon the browser politics of the newÂ project.

Mary Branscombe (The New Stack)

Smoothing Out the Scrolling Experience in Chrome on Android â€” A look at how the scrolling experience on Chrome for Android has been improved, reducing slow scrolling jank by 2x. The post shares how the Chromium team discovered and evaluated the problem, and how that helped them â€œdesign a better browser experience goingÂ forwardâ€.

Stephen Nusko (Google)

Optimizing Speed on eBay â€” â€œFor every 100 milliseconds improvement in search page loading time, eBay saw a 0.5% increase in â€˜Add to Cartâ€™ count.â€ â€”Â This perfectly highlights how important performance can be at such huge scale. Addy runs through just how the performance of eBayâ€™s sites and apps were optimized for a faster overall userÂ experience.

Addy Osmani

Addy didn't just stop with looking at eBay, he also took a look at YouTube's efforts to increase their Core Web Vitals pass rates.

Designing Accessible Text Over Images: Best Practices, Techniques, And Resources â€” The first in a two-part series in which Hannah Milan covers best practices when using various 'text over image' techniques. Lots of visuals here to help make theÂ point.

Smashing Magazine

The Future of Open Source: SaaS, the Final Frontier â€” Software has moved to the cloud â€¦ and open source is moving with it. Join SaaS leaders for the discussion on SeptÂ 7.

Sentry sponsor

â–¶Â Â Beyond The Hype: WebAssembly â€“ From the Browser to Beyond
Colin Eberhardt podcast

Assistive Technology Shouldnâ€™t Be a 'Mystery Box'
Christian Heilmann

UX is Not Dead, Itâ€™s Just Misunderstood
Nate Schloesser

ğŸ”§ Code, Tools & Resources

Typograms: A Way to Render ASCII Diagrams More Elegantly â€” An intriguing project out of Google that lets you â€˜drawâ€™ diagrams in plain ASCII text within special script tags and these will then be rendered into nicer looking versions in the browser. An interesting approach if Mermaid is too full on for yourÂ needs.

Sam Goto / Google

ğŸ’¡ Monodraw is a neat macOS app for drawing similar ASCII-basedÂ digrams.

svg-drawing: A Simple Canvas to Draw, "Replay", and Export SVG Line Art â€” You can deep link to any drawing, adjust some draw settings, and even change the options for playing back the drawing by animating theÂ lines. Please excuse my shoddy rocket drawing.

catsjuice

OGL 1.0: A Minimal WebGL Framework â€” WebGL is far from the easiest technology to use on its own, so libraries like Three.js are often used to make it more accessible. OGL has a similar motive while sticking closer to the WebGLÂ metal.

Nathan Gordon et al.

Vaul: An Unstyled Drawer Component for React â€” Also referred to as a â€œbottom sheetâ€, useful for mobile interfaces as a replacement for a dialog element and itâ€™s powered by Radix UIâ€™s dialogÂ component.

Emil Kowalski

ğŸ§‘â€ğŸ’» JOBS

Find Frontend Engineering Jobs with Hired â€” Hired makes job hunting easy-instead of chasing recruiters, companies approach you with salary details up front. Create a free profileÂ now.
Hired

Mobile FIRST: A Browser Extension to Simulate Different MobileÂ Devices â€” Available for Chrome and Firefox, itâ€™s useful for responsive testing and taking screenshots and GIFs for mockups andÂ presentations.

Mobile FIRST

MyTailwind: Interactively Customize Tailwind Components â€” Gives you a simple visual editor where you can customize styles for about 11 different components (button, navbar, card, sidebar, alert, etc.), then copy the HTML with the TailwindÂ classes.

Ashraful Malik

Maily: An Editor for Creating Beautiful, Pre-Designed, Mobile-Ready Emails
Arik Chakma

ğŸ® ...and finally

noclip â€”Â A Digital Web-Based Museum of Video GameÂ Levels â€” This neat site is a browser-based way to explore levels from a variety of classic games. Iâ€™ve just been exploring the castle grounds of Super Mario 64 and the streets of GTA IIIâ€™s Liberty City. A cool nostalgia trip if nothing else. RepoÂ here. Three cheers forÂ WebGL!

Jasper St. Pierre

The Browser Company

Google's 'Web Environment Integrity' Draft Draws Developer Ire â€” This is a developing story worth keeping an eye on. Google has proposed an idea called Web Environment Integrity (WEI) as a way for clients to establish their â€˜integrityâ€™ with a server by way of a third party. â€œIn simpler terms, WEI provides a way for a browser to prove it is working as a website operator expects, and hasnâ€™t been manipulated.â€ Unsurprisingly, many folks see where this couldÂ lead..

  • The folks at Devographics (the team behind the State of CSS) want your help in shaping the very first 'State of HTML' survey.

  • The third edition of the PNG spec has been published as a W3C WorkingÂ Draft.

Stefan Judis

Scroll Driven Animations in CSS are a Joy to Play Around With â€” A look at some of the fun we can have with scroll driven animations â€” giving us the chance to animate elements based on a scroll instead of time. This post looks at the basics, shares some ideas, and neatÂ demos.

Brecht De Ruyte

Sentry sponsor

WebGPU: The Cross-Platform Graphics API of Tomorrow? â€” Learn how to build an app with WebGPU (using C++) for the web and specificÂ platforms.

FranÃ§ois Beaufort

How to Use CSS object-fit and object-position â€” Learn how to use CSS object-fit to determine how images fit within a given space, and how to position those images with object-position.

Ralph Mason

Can We Query the Root Container? â€” The complexities of containment, overflow, and â€˜propagationâ€™.

Miriam Suzanne

Easy SVG Sparklines â€” With just a little SVG you can easily create sparkline charts thatâ€™ll render in the browser and donâ€™t require any JavaScript atÂ all.

Alex Plescan

The Rise of JPEG XL: Apple's Support and Image CompressionÂ Insights â€” On the significance of Appleâ€™s support for JPEG XL and what this means for the widespread adoption of this next-generation image compressionÂ format.

JON SNEYERS

It comes from the same folks as TUI Editor and TUI Calendar and while itâ€™s happy on its own, there are wrappers for Vue and React too. GitHubÂ repo.

NHN

wavesurfer.js 7: Audio Waveform Player â€” If youâ€™re creating a podcast player, audio experience, or anything where seeing an interactive audio waveform could be useful, check this out. GitHubÂ repo.

katspaugh and contributors

You Look Like You Could Use a T-Shirt. And a Better AuthÂ Provider â€” Spin up a local instance of FusionAuth in just 5 minutes. Send us a screenshot and weâ€™ll send you a t-shirt. It'sÂ free.

Detect Scroll: A Fast, Light JS Module for Detecting Scroll Activity â€” Expands on the browserâ€™s limited scroll event listener to allow you to accurately detect direction and location on bothÂ axes.

Jordan Egstad

Winded

Tabler Icons: Over 4500 Vector Icons for the Web â€” Open source icons you can use by either copying or downloading SVGs or PNGs or use one of the helper libraries like @tabler/icons-react to take them direct into a React app,Â say.

Tabler

React Tweet: A Fresh Way to Embed Tweets in a React App â€” Vercel has come up with an elegant way to embed posts from the site formerly known as Twitter that's faster and smaller than the official mechanism and supports React Server Components and â€˜any React framework.â€™ Now let's just hope Elon doesnâ€™t turn off theÂ taps..
